column1: Anacortes  is a city in Skagit County
column3: United States. The name "Anacortes" is an adaptation of the name of Anne Curtis Bowman
column4: who was the wife of early Fidalgo Island settler Amos Bowman. Anacortes' population was 15
column5: 778 at the time of the 2010 census. It is one of two principal cities of and included in the Mount Vernon-Anacortes Metropolitan Statistical Area.

column1: Anacortes was officially incorporated on May 19

column2: railroad surveyor and town founder Amos Bowman moved his family to the northern tip of Fidalgo Island. Bowman began promoting the area as an obvious terminus for the Northern Pacific Railway as it was built through the north Cascades to the Pacific. Bowman established the town's first newspaper
column3: The Northwest Enterprise
column4: to promote his vision of the New York of the West.Seattle and Northern Company began building a rail line from the town in 1888. Real estate and development boomed from 1888 to 1890 as a result of the railroad rumors
column5: and the Oregon Improvement Company posted $15 million in bonds to develop the town.

column2: the real estate bubble burst. Speculators lost money and the Oregon Improvement Company could no longer afford to complete tracks over the Cascades. The town failed to become the railroad terminus Bowman had envisioned.After the bust
column3: the town became prominent for its fishing tradition

column3: of which 11.75 square miles (30.43 km2) is land and 3.78 square miles (9.79 km2) is water.

column1: The median age in the city was 47.2 years. 19.6% of residents were under the age of 18; 6.3% were between the ages of 18 and 24; 21.4% were from 25 to 44; 29.9% were from 45 to 64; and 22.9% were 65 years of age or older. The gender makeup of the city was 47.9% male and 52.1% female.
Anacortes is on Fidalgo Island. Rosario Strait and the San Juan Islands are to the West while to the South
column2: Deception Pass separates Fidalgo and Whidbey Islands. To the East
column3: the Swinomish Channel separates Fidalgo Island from the mainland. The weather is milder than other areas of the Pacific Northwest
column4: because it lies within the Olympic Mountain rain shadow. Fidalgo Island gets 21 inches of rain per year
column5: only half as much as Seattle.

column2: Anacortes was established with a name and a post office in 1879 in the vain hope that it would be selected as the western terminus of the transcontinental railroad. The town was officially incorporated in 1891 shortly after the railroad bust
column3: and became a lumber and fishing center.

column2: oil companies built big refineries near Anacortes. Two of the five refineries operating in Washington are located near the town. One is owned and operated by Marathon Petroleum (opened in 1955
column3: it was originally built and owned by Shell Oil and later operated by Andeavor [formerly Tesoro])
column4: operating as the Marathon Anacortes Refinery
column5: the other is owned and operated by Shell Puget Sound Refinery Company (opening in 1957
column6: and originally built and owned by Texaco). Refining remains the area's largest industry
column7: but the economic base now includes yacht construction/shipbuilding
column9: and residential services for the nearby Whidbey Island Naval Air Station.

column1: Anacortes has a mayor–council government with an elected mayor and seven city councilmembers
column2: of whom three are elected from single member wards. The remaining four are elected at-large.

column1: The city government operates a municipal broadband system that began operation as a pilot in late 2019 and will expand to the entire city in 2023.

Anacortes is a popular destination for boaters and those traveling on to the San Juan Islands. The city maintains a 220-acre (0.89 km2) city park on the northwestern end of Fidalgo Island named "Washington Park". This park features camping
column3: and majestic views of the San Juan Islands. The most prominent view is of Cypress Island.

column1: As a result of Anacortes' proximity to the Strait of Juan de Fuca
column2: the area provides opportunities for whale-watching.  The waters off of Anacortes and Fidalgo Island offer numerous varieties of marine-life
column3: including three resident Orca pods.
800 acres (11 km2) with 50 miles (80 km) of mountain biking and hiking trails
column4: are a rare amenity in a city the size of Anacortes.  In adjacent Mount Erie Park
column5: a number of rock climbing routes are popular on the cliffs of the south and west faces of Mount Erie. Mount Erie offers scenic vistas from its 1273-foot peak.Anacortes hosts many long-distance cyclists
column6: as it is the western terminus of the Adventure Cycling Association's Northern Tier cross-country bicycle route

column1: Anacortes is also home to The Business
column2: a record store and concert venue voted Washington state's best record shop. Founded in 1978
column3: the store is notable for its many musicians who have worked there
column5: Phil Elverum and Karl Blau. The Business is located in the Alfred Olson Building which is part of the National Register of Historic Places.

column1: Shipwreck Day is a popular single-day
column2: flea market/town garage sale event held annually on the 3rd Saturday in July. City management accommodates the occasion by blocking off several downtown streets.

column1: What the Heck Fest was an annual festival coinciding with Shipwreck Day. It began in 2001 and held its last festival in 2019. The festival took place at various locations in Anacortes a week in the middle of July. Performers presented music
column3: literature
column4: and art. The thematic center of the festival is the dinner show that includes a full meal along with the concert

column1: The first weekend of August hosts the Anacortes Arts Festival.  Started in 1962 as the result of the efforts of a group of dedicated community arts patrons
column2: the festival is held in the midst of blocked-off downtown main street areas.  Vendors
column3: merchants
column4: and artisans present their wares in covered booths while jazz and blues musicians are showcased on four different stages.

column1: The Oyster Run is an annual one day biker-friendly motorcycle rally held on the fourth Sunday of September.  Beginning in 1981
column2: the event has grown into the largest rally in the Pacific Northwest
column3: with an estimated motorcycle count of 15000 bikes
column4: and growing in numbers each year.
